video.title_en: How to find the speed of light (Fizeau experiment)

summary.text_en: In 1849, French physicist Armand Fizeau conducted his famous 'toothed wheel experiment'. He passed a beam of light through a gap in a rapidly spinning cogwheel to a mirror 8.6 km away, reflecting it back. By adjusting the wheel's speed, he found the critical velocity where the returning light was blocked by the next 'tooth' (causing an eclipse). Using the rotation speed and distance, he calculated the speed of light to be ~313,300 km/s. This was the first time in history the speed of light was measured terrestrially, without relying on astronomical observations.
key_points_en: First terrestrial (non-astronomical) measurement of light speed
Proved light speed could be measured by mechanical experiment

story.text_en: Before Fizeau, measuring light speed relied on the vastness of space (like RÃ¸mer's Jupiter moons, `roemer_speed_of_light_1676`). Many thought light was too fast to measure over short Earth distances. Fizeau's challenge was measuring time in microseconds. His genius was converting 'time measurement' into 'mechanical measurement': he didn't need a stopwatch; he only needed to measure the gear's 'rotation speed'. He set up his apparatus between Montmartre (his father's balcony) and Suresnes. At 12.6 revolutions per second, the returning light was blocked. The experiment didn't just give a number; it set the standard for precision optical experimentation.

fun_facts.text_en: Fizeau is often confused with LÃ©on Foucault. They were friends and collaborators who had a falling out and became rivals. Foucault improved on Fizeau's experiment in 1862 (using a 'rotating mirror' instead of a 'cogwheel') to get a more accurate value (298,000 km/s).

Fizeau also conducted a famous 'water flow experiment' in 1851 to measure the speed of light in moving water. The result (Fizeau drag coefficient) later became one of the key experimental proofs for Einstein's Special Relativity.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Fizeau wanted to know how fast light runs. He had no stopwatch fast enough. So he used a 'light chopper' (a spinning gear).
He shot light out through a gap, it flew to a distant mirror and came back. This took a tiny bit of time.
During that time, if the gear spun fast enough, the returning light would hit a 'tooth' instead of the gap, and Fizeau would see darkness.
By calculating how fast the gear spun, he figured out how long the light took. He proved we could 'catch' light right here on Earth.

applications.text_en: The speed of light (c) is now the basis for defining the 'meter'. Fizeau's experiment was the first step in establishing c as a measurable physical constant.

applications.text_en: The principle used by modern tech (Radar, Lidar) to measure distance (Time-of-Flight) is essentially the electronic version of Fizeau's experiment.

impact.text_en: The Fizeau experiment brought the speed of light down from the heavens into the physics lab. It proved that even a speed as immense as light's could be measured terrestrially with clever mechanics. Refining this number (later by Foucault and Michelson) was crucial for Maxwell (`maxwell_equations_1861`) to confirm that light is an electromagnetic wave.

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: With a gear and two mirrors, Fizeau caught the fastest thing in the universe right here on Earth.

quiz.question_en: How did Fizeau's experiment determine that the light had made the round trip?
options_en: By observing the light disappear (eclipse) as it was blocked by a 'tooth' of the spinning wheel
By measuring the color change of the light
By the reading on a galvanometer
quiz.explanation_en: The key was 'chopping' the light. When the wheel spun at just the right speed so that a 'tooth' replaced the 'gap' in the exact time the light took to travel back and forth, the light would be blocked (eclipsed) from the observer's view. This speed gave the time.
